Yiquan/Dachengquan

Yiquan is a Chinese martial art and exercise system. It is focused specifically on the mental aspects of the Xing Yi Quan exercise system. During this activity, the techniques of "zhan zhuang" (standing meditation) and "shi li" (testing force) are performed. During the standing meditation, participants practice proper posture in order to maintain a correct body balance. This is based on the premise that one must know how to "stand for health" before they "stand for combat." During the testing force, participants apply the processes developed in the standing meditation element, with the aim of releasing the force accumulated in one quick burst.
Through the practice of standing meditation, visualization techniques, slow and fast movement, push hands and sparring, Yiquan is a complete system that develops internal health, power, and effective fighting ability.

Our mission

Opportunity

To give our members the opportunity to learn and perform a traditional martial art that has been passed down for many centuries.

Challenge

To challenge ourselves to realize our physical potential and achieve excellence in the Yiquan martial art.

Empower

To empower our members to break through the traditional stereotypes and limited roles.

Team

To build teamwork and cooperation among each other.

Zhang zhuang practice

Zhan zhuang (站樁) Standing pole postures where emphasis is put on natural condition, working to improve listening to the body and on developing hunyuan li, "Natural living force" or "all things that make the whole".
The roots of standing practice go back long ago. Even before the martial arts were mentioned standing postures were practiced independently as we know them today. Yiquan is a part of 200 original postures that were once practiced by real Taoists, not religious, but philosophical practitioners. From these 200 postures Baguazhang was developed, which was initially just a way of meditation and inner cultivation. Historic events in the society aided towards developing more defensive practices such as those hidden martial applications in Baguazhang. Others would be, as fans of internal martial arts already know, Taijiquan, before lightly introduced Xingyiquan and one which is not usually mentioned, however it deserves mentioning, Liuhebafa (Liu He Ba Fa).

Continue reading

Tuishou practice

Tuishou is an important part of the traditional Yichuan training. It’s practiced with other person to develop the energy of listening and putting into practice what we have learned. Yichuan pushing hands builds your strength and flexibility of the muscles of your legs, building the central union between the upper and lower part of the body. “Tui Shou – pushing hands”, aims to train your power dynamics, power change, body work, etc. The goal is to control your partner, by destabilize his force and bringing yourself into an advantageous position. Tu Shou and San Shou are both free sparring exercises.
